body:
+1 on sending activation completion messages over Kafka. I don't think we can get rid of Cloudant polling entirely though. It needs to be a fallback in case the controller dies before processing the message.

Also, I imagine you'd want the completion message to be directed to a particular controller rather than broadcast to all controllers.
Ok, we can keep it as is, and fix the issues I mentioned for both pollen and forecast together in a separate commit.
@visahak Can you rebase your commits? If it passes Travis again, I'll merge it into master.
You're right it should be there.

Here's a sample of what it should contain:

```
OPEN_WHISK_DB_HOST=
OPEN_WHISK_DB_PORT=
OPEN_WHISK_DB_USERNAME=
OPEN_WHISK_DB_PASSWORD=
```
@starpit can you pls elaborate on how you envision the annotation of activations to work?
You have a valid couch or cloudant configuration file? You can check the log files in `/tmp/wsklogs/invoker0/` it should have a reason for the failure to deploy.

i believe that @rabbah already has this support in the backend, though it is not exposed through the controller as of today

the thought is that we'd have a PUT/POST call which takes an activation ID and an annotation record e.g. `{key: "end-to-end-response-time-in-millis", value: 300}`, and the backend would merge this annotation into the existing annotation map of the given activation. we'll also need to expose a GET to fetch an activation's annotations (or perhaps this would show up, as with other entities, at the LIST level of detail, given that they are annotations).

More precisely the REST API does not permit a PUT on activations. They otherwise are the same as other entities in terms of their schema. So we can define a PUT (not POST) operation to activations which accepts only annotations and these are merged with the activation record. The user may use these activations as they like for example to add a note to the activation, to label it, or store other meta data. 

The UI and CLI clients can use it to store relevant information as well.

Current activation result is on the following: 

GET .../activations/123

```
{
  "name": "echo",
  "subject": "guest",
  "activationId": "123",
  "publish": false,
  "annotations": [],
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "response": {
    "result": {
      "message": "Hello"
    },
    "success": true,
    "status": "success"
  },
  "end": 1459520294085,
  "logs": [],
  "start": 1459520294077,
  "namespace": "guest"
}
```

@rabbah , do you envision something like that? 

GET  .../activations/123?excludeMetadata=true

```
"response": {
    "result": {
      "message": "Hello"
    },
    "success": true,
    "status": "success"
  },
```

On the CLI:

```
wsk -v activation get 123 --excludeMetadata
```

This is related to the `actions` API not the `activations` API endpoints. A request to invoke an action via `POST /actions/name?blocking=true` currently returns an activation record `W` as the one you showed above. Instead I am suggesting `POST /actions/name?blocking=true&result=true` to return `W.response.result` instead for a successful activation (status code 200).

i can imagine a good system-internal use case (eg the load balancer adding an annotation with roundtrip time for a blocking invocation), but what is the (high prio) use case for externalizing this?

when millions of activations are getting produced as a result of invoking actions in a high-load scenario, it also seems like a perf-costly scenario to add annotations to each activation.
Looks good.

There is nothing more you need to do more in Bluemix.

In the top level directory there is a file called template-cloudant-local.env copy it and edit the contents: The username and password from  Bluemix are filled out it template file  so you can create the required cloudant-local.env.

Hmm. The cloudant username from Bluemix should be a uuid followed by `-bluemix`. You can verify that you can login to the cloudant dashboard on cloudant.com.

Yes, definitely to the specific originating controller using an instance topic as in the way it get to the invoker.  I think of it as a completion mechanism which happens to carry the message.  As such, I agree it will have to deal with a lack of ack if the invoker dies.

The next step (work about to start on this) will the the final merge.  **Does it suffice to simply disable the deployment of the load balancer?**

spawned PG 208

AFAIK, our core (Scala) components log time in UTC already. They all (should) use `Logging.scala`. See [this](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/common/scala/src/whisk/common/Logging.scala#L103). 

I'm fine with your proposal, specially that I don't think we'll notice a difference wrt logs.
Already passed pg 206. It needs a companion pr.

Merged. Closing.
please rebase
#153 has all the info.

Hi rabbah.
I finally went thru the configuration of cloudant on bluemix. Thanks to the instructions here:
https://developer.ibm.com/open/2016/02/22/openwhisk-a-quick-tech-preview/.

I finally realized that the username and password need to be retrieved via the command like "cf service-key cloudant-for-openwhisk openwhisk". However, I took my bluemix username and bluemix password at first, which was the reason I did not get the cloudant running on top of bluemix.

My suggestion is that we can add an additional sentence in the README like "the username and password should be retrieved via what kind of command." instead of "Make note of the username and password so you can create the required cloudant-local.env", which can mislead the users to pick up the bluemix username and password.

The instructions you refer to are actually from this project's README file: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk#create-a-cloudant-account-via-ibm-bluemix

In Bluemix, from the dashboard, you can click on the Cloudant service instance you want to retrieve the credentials, click its corresponding tile and click `Service Credentials` from the left nav bar.

I was following exactly what is written here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk#create-a-cloudant-account-via-ibm-bluemix, but still got confused at the beginning and messed up with the bluemix username and password. 
I still think it is a good idea to add more explanation to avoid further confusion to folks who are at the early stage of openwhisk.
Thanks for the feedback - will tweak the docs.
pg 208 post rebase, and perf pg 285 post-(post-rebase)-rebase

Yes we do. The second build is local to the machine though, while the first build builds the images at whatever machine you specified as `main`. Some tests need those images to be available at the executing machine.

Those tests should properly define these images as dependencies, which will remove the necessity to build them everytime.
Could we build once and `pull` to the machines where the tests run? (I thought that was what we were doing.)

I'ld rather decouple those tests from a whole build at all. The `actionContainer` tests only have those images as a dependency, which they should specify. A mechanism then needs to either `build` or `pull` these images, which I'ld deem an implementation detail.

Currently, there might be cases where a build happens remotely, but not populating a registry, making a `pull` not feasible currently.
merged

Hi @seriousme thanks for your excellent input.

I think it is a great idea to have the stack as compose topology on dockerhub. 

Before we do that we should first reduce the image sizes so ppl won't have to download huge chunks.

Most images are based on whisk/scala which itself is pretty large. That itself can be reduced imho.

As for the consul part, we are currently working on moving to ansible for our deployment. During that process we are also looking into ways to reduce overhead on common tools such as consul which we currently build ourselves. So chances are we got rid of that image soon.
userland network creation and iptables rules are moved elsewhere for the moment.
@domdom82 are the deletions of the loadbalancer, controller, kafka ymls by purpose?
@jeremiaswerner  yes. the component playbooks are now living under /ansible/roles. they were just moved.
Merged as 64b74938c7eb113a3c8e78444f3ae2b20f65974a
Given the :+1: I'll rebase, and make all code conforming.

@domdom82 Thanks for the positive feedback :-)

I found a relatively small scala package [frolvlad](https://hub.docker.com/r/frolvlad/alpine-scala/) based on Alpine Linux. Now I'm not a Scala expert, so I might be way off here, but alpine-scala is build on alpine-java (oracle jdk) which in turn is build on Alpine.  

However if you want to stay main stream there is also a [docker java base image](https://hub.docker.com/_/java/) which might be used as a starter to a Scala image.

Ideally there would imho be a few docker compose files: 
- one that uses cloudant as its DB
- one that uses a couchdb container as its DB (preferably with a separate data volume)

I noticed my repository on the VM also contains a CLI container, I would include that as well in the compose files.

Last point: the couchdb container is the only one started without a predefined name in [start-couchdb-box.sh](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/db/couchdb/start-couchdb-box.sh#L30), adding a --name parameter would make it easier to reference it, and it just looks more clean as all the other containers have nice names :-)

Cheers,
Hans
Sure, can rename.  It was named this way before (also was a staged computation) so I preserved it.
If only I knew who did that!
PG 296 almost passed - probably stray errors.  Fixing issues, rebasing, and retesting.

~~Re-retrying after fixes and rebase.  
IPG 210 just passed.  However, Travis failed - might be stale/transient - rebuilding.
Retesting with IPG 211 and Travis.~~

Need to do work to handle activator.

Everything except rules is working because the activator needs to talk to the load balancer which no longer exists.  ~~One alternative is to add these routes back to the controller but this seems a bit silly as we are about to get rid of the activator.  Since this is going reasonably fast, Rodric and I think we can just expand this work item to include merging the activator in as well.~~

**Update**  So of the 3 alternatives, we are going with the third one.
1. Just run a separate load balancer.  This was falsely attractive in that it worked right out of the box - discovered by accident.  The load balancer's DoS and who knows what else is not able to deal with this scenario so let's not accidentally scale the load balancer.
2. Integrate activator into controller now.  The activator needs significant rework and also does complicated things like dynamically update topics.  Seems too involved to move it at this point.
3. Add route to the controller to handle existing activator -> loadbalancer.  Just add a new route (inaccessible to user) to the controller that allows the activator to talk to the internal loadbalancer.
Per @perryibm s feedback, I included a special case for when the timeout hits to know if a process was killed or exited non-zero on its own.

You're right, good catch! GUI is only necessary if you choose to install the Ubuntu Desktop. That could be made clear in `README.md`
We could disable it by default. Would not even use it on desktop.

Recent discussion has brought up the problems with fetching logs from user containers making this a non-trivial issue.

Current ideas for mitigation would be:
- `docker logs --since=nnn containerid` to fetch logs instead. needs to be evaluated on performance impact.
- customizing log driver to write into a different file. no apparent option available at least for the json driver. we could only limit log size with regard to security concerns.

From a RAS perspective, you can't rely on any infrstratucture container to do any followup action in the event of unexpected termination.  There is no normal shutdown path for the invoker and even adding one does not remove the job of dealing with an unexpected termination.  

We do in fact unpause/rm in teardown of VMs during testing.

The two problems are orthogonal in my point of view. Yes, containers can crash at any time which is why there are nannies in place. But if you allocate stuff you should make sure to deallocate on exit just like the old days of malloc() and free().

Another way of dealing with this could a more fine-grained way of teardown that can be tailored to invoker-only stuff. I.e. if I had a regex for all action containers I could unpause + rm them. 

For ansible I need a way of un-deploying exactly one component without tearing down everything else.

Option 3 from above was implemented successfully.  The code has been successfully merged.

There was a final tweak to fix the fact that there was a load balancer hot swap test that started an errant load balancer.  Removal of this test closes the loop.

Take consul for example: If a server in the cluster gets terminated, it leaves the cluster and notifies the master about that. It doesn't just die and lets the others find out via timeout. Now of course a crash can still happen in which case RAS kicks in. However a graceful shutdown is also important.
I can confirm that I can run tests from cmd line. I have to still check Eclipse. Trying to sort some unrelated  Eclipse issues after the new work on the loadbalancer.
I can also run tests from Eclipse. I'll shortly merge this into master.
Is it too much to put this in a `CloudantDbRestClient` which extends `CouchDbRestClient`?
